After they were taken, I searched the place where they had been standing, and found five half-sovereigns—I went to the station, came out, and made further search, and found this purse thrown over into the ruins in Plum tree-street, just opposite where I found the half-sovereigns—both the prisoners had been near that spot.

JOHN O'BRIEN . I keep a beer-house at Nos. 7 and 8, George-Street, Bloomsbury. I remember the morning when the prisoners were taken—Sea
ger came to my place between seven and eight o'clock, and staid for half an hour—he asked me for a pint of the best ale, but being a little in liquor I would not serve him—I said the best plan would be to go home—a few minutes after be went out, as there was a disturbance at the end of the stone-yard.

COURT. Q. Do you know anything of the other witnesses who are com
ing? A. I know some of them, not all—several of them frequent my house—Stewart does occasionally—Tool lives next door to me—he was in my house at that time—Seager has been long in the habit of coming in occasion
ally—he is a tailor, and lives in Church-street, Soho—I always shut up at twelve o'clock at night, and open at eight, or sometimes at seven, in the morning—I always shut up the bar at twelve o'clock—a few single young men lodge with me—sometimes I have twenty; sometimes more or less—I have two houses, with a communication between them—when I shut the bar the lodgers come in at the private door—they go out sometimes at five or six o'clock in the mom ing—I am up till about two—if they do not come in by that hour I shut them out—they have no key—I keep the key.

JAMES STEWART . I am a hair-dresser, and live at No. 1, George-street, Bloomsbury. On the 2nd of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning, I saw a female come round the corner, and the prosecutor came after her—he was very drunk—the female ran into a passage—Seager was not there at that time.

COURT. Q. How long have you lived at No. 1? A. About nine months—I know O'Brien—I have sent for a pint of beer there, and have been in the house—he comes and is shaved at my shop—he keeps a beer-shop—I do not know whether Seager lodges there—it is a lodging-house for single men—I only know Seager by coming to my shop to be shaved—I am not much friends with him.

CHARLES TOOL . I live at No. 6, George-street. I went into O'Brien's house about half-past seven o'clock that morning, and saw Seager there—he appeared tipsy, and O'Brien refused to serve him—I went next door, and in about five minutes I heard a disturbance in the street—I went out, and saw Seager in custody.

COURT. Q. Who lives next door to O'Brien? A. I do—I am a shoe
maker—I know Mr. O'Brien, and some of the persons who lodge in his house—I do not see any of them here.

ELIZA SMITH . I live with my mother. On the morning of the 2nd of August I was going to work, at a little after seven o'clock—I was thirsty, and called in at the public-house at the corner of Plumtree-street—I saw the pro
secutor, very drunk, with three females—he staggered and fell—one of the

females pulled him up, placed him against a barrel, and told him to stand there—one of them winked at the other who had no bonnet on, to come out—they came out—one went towards George-street, and two towards Holborn—the prosecutor went towards George-street, after the woman who went there—neither of the prisoners were there.
COURT. Q. How long have you known Seager? A. I do not know him—I did not see him there.

Lloyd's Defence. I was going home and speaking to a young friend, when they took me up—the prosecutor came and said in the station, if I would give him two sovereigns he would not prosecute; if not, he would go as far as the law would allow him.
(—Cole, of Well-street; William Seard, of Hart-street;—Coleman, of King-street, Corent-garden; and—Harraden, a tailor; gave Seager a good character.)

LLOYD—
GUILTY . Aged 27.—

SEAGER—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—

2490.
JOHN DONOVAN , and
JOHN DONOVAN the Younger, were indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of August, 1 cap, value 4s. 6d., the goods of
Robert Hannah; and that John Donovan the elder had bees before con
victed of felony.

DONOVAN, jun., pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 10.—
Confined Nine Days.

SARAH HANNAH . I am the wife of Robert Hannah; we live in Welling
ton-place, Back-road. On the 5th of August I went into the front parlour to open my shutters—there was a new blue cloth cap on the table, and soon after it was gone.

GEORGE GALLIERS . I live in Wellington-street. I saw two boys stand
ing by the prosecutor's window—one was lae, and had a crutch—that was John Donovan the elder—he went inside the door, and appeared to be listen
ing—he then came out and spoke to his companion, who was a smaller boy—the smaller one then went in, and came out with a blue cap in his hand—Donovan, junior, is about the size of the smaller boy, but I cannot swear to him.
Donovan, sen. He only saw me looking in at the window.

ROBERT BOARD
police-constable K 332.) I produce a certificate of John Donovan, senior's, former conviction, which I got from Mr. Ellis's office, in Clerkenwell—(read)—he is the person.

JOHN DONOVAN, sen.—
GUILTY . Aged 16.— Transported for

2491.
JOHN HAMILTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of July, 1 jacket, value 16s., the goods of
Jacob Galpin.

JACOB GALPIN . I live in Garden-court, Whitechapel. I took the prisoner in from charity, and on the 6th of August, about eight o'clock in the morning, my wife missed my jacket, and when I came home to dinner I missed it—I afterwards met the prisoner in the Greenwich-road—I charged him with it—he said he had been in London on the Friday, and had made it all right with my wife, and paid her for it—I gave him in charge.
ELLEN GALPIN . I am the prosecutor's wife. I missed the jacket—the prisoner never came to me on the Friday to make it right.
Prisoner's Defence. I got up in the morning, and came down; I had no jacket on, no more than I have now.

GUILTY . Aged 54.—
Confined Four Months.

2492.
ELIZA MARTIN was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of July, 1 parasol, value 2s. 6d.; 3 yards and a half of ribbon, 4s. 6d.; and 1 hand. kerchief, 3d.; the goods of
James Foreman.
JAMES FOREMAN . The prisoner lodged with me—I one day found a for of the prisoner's which fitted my kitchen—I went to the pawnbroker's and found this parasol which is mine.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Show me your mark on it? A. I have another at home to match it—this is not the colour it was when I lost it—it has been dipped since—it was a light drab one—I know it by tie handle, and the size and every thing about it.
GEORGE FINNIGAN . I am a pawnbroker. This parasol was pledged I believe by the prisoner—the silk has been dyed.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose it is not the first parasol you hare seen that has been dyed? A. No—I can undertake to say that this has been dyed from a light colour to a dark one—here is a place where it has not taken the dye.
COURT. Q. Could they have dyed the silk without taking it to pieces? A. I do not know.
NOT GUILTY .

2493.
JOHN LEE was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of July, 1 sove
reign, the monies of
Robert Stanhope Wilks, his master.

JANE BUNYAN . I am in the service of Robert Stanhope Wilks. On the 12th of July. I gave the prisoner a sovereign to pay for some boots—he did not return—I never saw him till the 11th of Aug., when he was taken.
Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Had he been long in the prosecutor's employ? A. Six or seven months.
FREDERICK LITCHFIELD (police-constable M 50.) I took the prisoner—he said he had stolen the sovereign, and was sorry for it.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Month.

2494.
ELIZA SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of Aug., 9 yards and a half of printed cotton, value 4s. ll 1/2 d.; the goods of
Thomas Dimmock Gibbs, and another.

JOHN STONE SNOW . I am in the service of Thomas Dimmock Gibbs, and James Gibbs—they are linen drapers—on the 9th of Aug., the prisoner came to look at some dresses—a young man showed her some, and while he turned to get some more I saw the prisoner take a dress, and put it under her arm—I let her purchase a dress, and when she was going out I took the parcel, and asked her to let me do it up better—I took the dress from under her arm—she said she would pay for it if I would let her go—I gave her in charge.

Prisoner. I took up a dress thinking that I should like it better than the one I bought—the prosecutor said should he put it in paper—I said, "No," and put it down on the counter. Witness. No—she bought one which came to 3s. 3 1/2 d.—this one came to 4s. 11 1/2 d.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2495.
MARY KING was indicted
for stealing, on the 7th of Aug., 1 ihawl, value 5s.; the goods of
John Kemp; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

MARTHA LEVENE . I was standing near Mr. Kemp's shop on the 7th of Aug.—I saw the prisoner take a shawl which hung at his door—I did not we her unpin it, but she dragged it down—there were three together—she took the middle one, and put it under her own shawl—I gave information.
Prisoner. Q. Why should you iwcar to me when there were, other girls round? A. There was no one but you.
WILLIAM WAEEHAM . I am shopman, to John Kemp. I ran after the prisoner to Reform-place—I went to a house I saw the prisoner in, and a man gave me the shawl from under the table—it is my master's.
Prisoner. Did not I say I did not know wheie it was. Witness, No—you laid, "Let me go, and say I dropped it."

STEPHEN REEVE . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convic
tion, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2496.
THOMAS GRIFFITHS was indicted
for breaking and entering the shop of
John Throgood Roffway, on the 8th of Aug., at St. Michael, Wood-street, and stealing therein, 8 paintings and frames, value 28l.; his pro
perty, and that he had been before convicted of felony.
JOHN THROGOOD ROFFWAY . I am a house painter, and have a shop at No. 9, Huggin-lane, Wood-street. I left my shop on the 8th of Aug.—I afterwards found that these paintings were gone—these are mine.

ROBERT RAMSEY . I am shopman to Mr. Roffway. On the evening of the 8th of Aug., I left the shop locked up quite safe—I came back about nine o'clock the next morning—I found the back door open—it had been opened by a key, and these paintings were gone.

ROBERT KENDREW . I am a pawnbroker. On the morning of the 9th of Aug., the prisoner pawned this painting for 30s.—on the Saturday following I saw an account in the paper that the painting was stolen—I sent to the prosecutor who identified it.

Prisoner. The master said he did not think it was me—they took me to the station, found the duplicate on me, and then the master swore I was the person, and this witness came the next day and swore I was the man. Witness. A man brought the prisoner to the shop—he doubled his fist at him and threatened him—I desired him to take him to the station, and tickets were found on him which correspond with the name he gave me, George Lovell.

ROBERT PEARSON (City police-constable, No. 547.) I produce a certifi
cate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2497.
ELIZABETH JOLLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Aug., 1 shawl, value 1s.; the goods of
William Witherstone.
MARY ANN WITHERSTONE . I am the wife of William Witherstone. I let the prisoner sleep at my house for one night, and when she went the next day, I missed the shawl produced which is mine.
JANE JOHNSON . I searched the prisoner at the station—I found this shawl pinned round her body, under her gown.
Prisoner. It is my first offence.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2498.
GEORGE GAZOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Aug., 8 yards of oil-cloth, value 1s.; and 8 yards of printed moleskin, 11s.; the goods of
George King.
WILLIAM SHEPHERD . I am servant to George King, who keeps a shop. I received information, and saw a man pass me with something on his shoulder, like this property—this is my master's.
WILLIAM THOMAS ROSE . I saw the prisoner turn round Smith-street with
something on his arm—I ran and caught him in Spencer-street—he threw this cloth off his shoulder.

Prisoner. I was coming out of Goswell Street-road, and heard the cry of, "Stop thief," and ran. Witness. I am certain he had it—I ran, caught him, and held him till the policeman came—he made a strike at me.

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2499.
ROBERT LANHAM,
JOHN MANN , and
MARY MANN were indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of Aug., 5 10l. and 6 5l. Bank notes, the monies of
Edward Roach, from his person.

EDWARD ROACH . I am a dealer. I lost my watch, and was going about—Lanham and John Mann came up to me, and told me not to be frightened, it was all right, they would assist me to find my watch—I took them into a public-house in Essex-street, and called for some beer—I laid my head on the table, and went to sleep—the landlord awoke me, and asked me if my money was right—I felt, and missed from my pocket 80l. in Bank of England notes, which I had received from Barnetts and Co., for a check for 100l.

MARTHA EDMONDS . I am the wife of Thomas Edmonds, and live at the Catherine Wheel, in Essex-street. The prosecutor came in, and fell asleep—the three prisoners were there—Lanham put his hand into the prosecutor's pocket, and took something out—he wanted to escape, but my husband would not let him go—John Mann appeared to be asleep on the other side of the prosecutor, and Mary was by his side—I said something to them, and Mary Mann and Lanham said they were all friends together—Mary Mann whispered to Lanham a great deal—Mary and Lanham wanted to go, but I would not let them—Lanham then went into the yard—my husband followed him—he left the house, and my husband fetched him back with the notes in his pocket.

JOHN THOMAS EDMONDS . When I got home my wife told me something—I went into the tap-room—Lanham was on one side of the prosecutor, and John Mann on the other—I saw the prosecutor's pocket right up—I seised Lanham, and said, "What are you about? I will suffer nothing wrong in my house"—Lanham said, "We are all friends, let this man have his nap out"—I said, "Let him have it, but you shan't go"—Lanham went into the yard—I followed him—I awoke the prosecutor, and said, "Search and see what you have lost"—he said, "I have got a 5l. note changed," and he had got some silver and gold—I then said the prisoners might go, I begged their par
don—I then heard the prosecutor cry out, "I have lost 80l."—Lanham had got out—I ran out, and challenged him with not paying for the beer—he came back, and at that moment I turned the key, and sent for a policeman—he was searched, and 80l. in notes found in his breeches' pocket.
Lanham. I took the notes out of my pocket. Witness. Yes, I took them directly; he said they were counterfeits.

EDWARD ROACH
re-examined. I never knew the prisoners before.
John Mann's Defence. I was fast asleep.

LANHAM—
GUILTY . Aged 54.

J. MANN—
GUILTY . Aged 31.

M. MANN—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

2500.
JAMES REEVES was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, 1 bonnet, value 1s., the goods of
Joshua Reeves; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Nine Days, and
Whipped.

2501.
ANN LACEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of July, 1 shawl, value 7s., the goods of
Ann May; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

ANN MAY . I live in Union-court, Westminster. On the 6th of July I was asleep, and was awoke at two or three o'clock—I missed this shawl, looked out of the window, and saw the prisoner put it under her arm—she was going away with it.
BENJAMIN BAKER . I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pledged this shawl on the 6th of July.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the shawl.

ROBERT SUTTLE (police-constable B 97.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soners former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2502.
JAMES O'NEIL and
JAMES JOHN FITZGERALD were in
dicted for
stealing, on the 21st of Aug., 48 pairs of boots, value 5l., the goods of
Edward Wright; in a certain vessel in a port of entry and discharge.

JAMES CROW . I am mate of the Leven Lass, which is lying at Poplar; Edward Wright is the captain. On the 17th of Auga 1 received a trunk on board—I left the vessel at half-past five o'clock in the evening of the 25th of Aug., O'Neil was on board—I came back, and was on board—the dog barked in the night—I came on deck, and found Fitzgerald there—he is a seaman, and O'Neil was an apprentice—I have missed these boots—they are part of the cargo, and were in this trunk—they were picked up alongside the vessel.

HENRY SKIPP . I went on board, and informed the captain that a trunk of shoes had been picked up afloat in the dock—he called O'Neil, and asked him some questions, and O'Neil, said he knew all about it—I went down stairs with him—O'Neil gave me the key of his box—I unlocked it, and took twenty-six pair of these boots—there were eight dozen pair of boots in the box that was floating about—Fitzgerald was in bed—O'Neil said in his pre
sence that he had given them him to put into his box—Fitzgerald denied it, and said before the Magistrate that he knew O'Neil had put them into his box, but he did not give them to him.

ROBERT TAYLOR . I am an officer—I said, "I have picked up eight dozen pair of boots, and what has become of the others?—O'Neil said, "They are in the forecastle"—we opened the trunk with the key that O'Neil gave up—I took out twenty-four pairs, and the other officer took out twenty-four pairs—Fitz-gerald said, "I wish I had been dead hefore this had happened."

MOSS HART . I sent these boots and shoes to the ship, under the prose
cutor's care.

O'Neil. The dog made a noise, Fitzgerald came to me in my bed, and asked if my chest was open, I said it was—next morning I opened it, and saw parcels made up in it—I said I would keep them till I knew where they came from—I intended to ask the captain about them—if I had known they were stolen I would not have left them in it.

JAMES CROW
re-examined. Any one on board had access to these trunks—I found Fitzgerald on the fore-part of the vessel—he had no business there that I know of—I asked what was the matter—he said he was taken sud
denly ill.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
2503.
JOHN CONNELLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Aug., 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Donigan, from his person.

THOMAS DONIGAN . I live in Robert-street, Bedford-row. At five o'clock in the afternoon of the 21st of Aug., I was going throngh a crowd in St. Giles's—I felt something at my pocket—I immediately missed my handkerchief—I

turned, and saw the prisoner—I caught hold of him, and accused him—he said he had not had it—he attempted to get away—I saw the corner of my handkerchief out of his pocket—I laid hold of it—the policeman came up and took it and the prisoner—this is it.
Prisoner. Q. How far was I from you? A. About a yard and a half.

ESAU ROWLEY (police-sergeant E 4.) I took the prisoner and this hand
kerchief—when I came up it was hanging out of the prisoner's pocket, and the prosecutor drew it out.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw it on the ground, took it up, and put it into my pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.

2504.
HENRY BAKER,
ROBERT BAKER,
ANN JOHNSON , and
CAROLINE WILLIAMS , were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of Aug., 4 sovereigns, the monies of
Jonathan Davies, from his person.

JONATHAN DAVIES . I am a labourer, and live in Windsor-court, Falcon-square. On the 8th of Aug. I had just arrived from Canada—I had 16l. 3s. in money—I met with Bowden, and went with him to a public-house—I then went to buy a hat—I parted with Bowden in Finsbury-square, and took a cab in Aldgate, which Henry Baker drove—I told him to drive to Falcon-square—I got to the Lock and Key, in Smithfield—I did not tell the prisoner to stop there—I had something to drink—I was sober when I left Bowden—Henry Baker brought some beer to the door of the cab, and I drank some—I was not quite sober when I got to the Lock and Key—I showed the money to the landlady—I believed I put it again into my pocket-book—next morn
ing I found myself at the police-station, and somebody had taken all my money.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you remember taking Johnson and Williams into the cab? A. No—I parted with Bowden about eight o'clock—I will not say that I did not stop the cab, and get out myself into the public-house—I bad sixteen sovereigns and 3s. at first, and I bought a hat, which cost 8s.

JOHN BOWDEN . I am employed in the London Docks. I have known the prosecutor four years—I met him about four o'clock in the afternoon—he was sober—we went to the Bricklayers' Arms, in Back Church-lane—we had three pots of half-and-half between three of us—I took him to the hatter's, and there I first saw his money—I should say he had from ten to fourteen sovereigns—he opened his pocket-book to take one out to pay for his hat—we went to Aldgate, and took a cab, which H. Baker drove to Clifton-street, Finsbury-market, and I got out there—I left the prosecutor, and for 6d. more H. Baker was to drive him to Falcon-square—when I left him his money was safe that I had seen at the hatter's—he was sober—this was at half-past seven.

MARIA WILD . My father keeps the Lock and Key in Smithfield. On the evening of the 8th of August the prosecutor came with a cab-man about nine o'clock—there was a little boy on the box—they stood at the bar, and had some half-and-half and two glasses of gin—the prosecutor threw some so
vereigns on the counter—I do not know how many—he was not sober—H. Baker asked me to persuade him to put his money into his pocket-book—he did so—they then took their half-and-half into the tap-room.
Cross-examined. Q. He threw his money about like a drunken man? A. Yes—there was a gentleman at the counter, but no ladies—I did not see him put his pocket-book into his pocket.

ABRAHAM LAZARUS . I am a dealer in unredeemed pledges, and live in Tenter-street, Spitalfields. About half-past ten o'clock on this night I was in the Vinegar-ground—I gaw a cab driving very furiously—it nearly knocked me down—Henry Baker drove, and Robert was on the box with him—I said, "Can't you mind where you are driving?"—he made some answer, which I did not hear—he drove on—the cab came up Vincent-street, and turned round Catherine-street—it stopped there—both the men got down from the box—Henry opened the door, and Robert laid hold of something, which appeared to me to be a bundle, but which turned out to be the prosecutor—he was bundled out into the road—Johnson and Williams were in the cab—Johnson had a black bonnet on, and Williams had a straw bonnet on—Johnson was pushing the prosecutor out—Williams was coming out of the cab, and was shoved back by Johnson—the cab drove off—I halloed out, "Pick up your bundle"—they went on—I went up, and found it was the prosecutor in a helpless state—I gave directions, and the cab was brought back.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How near were you to the cab? A. About ten yards—I do not speak to the faces of Johnson or Williams, only to their bonnets.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you buy goods of pawn
brokers? A. I do—I have never acted as an attorney for prisoners in my life—I might have given a brief over for prisoners as their friend, not deriving any profit—I did not know them before—they were no friends of mine—I did it for nothing—I was tried seven years ago for a bedstead which I bought—to the best of my belief there was three sovereigns and some silver lying about on the pavement—when the cry was made the neighbours came out—I am not living in a brothel, nor constantly in brothels—I was looking for a lady that night.

JAMES DAWSON . I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Catherine-street. About half-past ten o'clock that night I was standing at my door—I saw the cab stop, and, after a time, drive off again as hard as it could drive—some one who was with me attracted my attention—I went where the cab stopped, and found the prosecutor.

JAMES FARRELL (police-constable N 145.) About eleven o'clock this night I saw the cab in the Vinegar-ground—Henry and Robert Baker were on the box—Johnson and Williams were inside—it was going very fast—we were called to stop it—I turned round the corner, and saw the prosecutor—I looked on the ground, and found three sovereigns and a half-crown—Lazarus called my attention to the money—I got the prosecutor into the cab, and took charge of Johnson and Williams, who were in the cab—another officer got oh the box—Williams began crying and wringing her hands, and said several times she knew she should be transported now—I was supporting the prosecutor's head, and noticed Johnson stoop down—her hand slipped along my leg—when I got to the station I got a light, and found one sovereign, two half-sovereigns, 2s. and one halfpenny in the cab—I searched Robert Baker, and found 9s. 2d. on him.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You found nothing on Williams? A. No.

JAMES CAFFRAY (police-constable N 153.) I was in Old-street Road, and heard the cry of "Policeman, stop the cab "—I looked round, and saw the cab coming furiously towards me—I ran and stopped it—I took H. and R. Baker into custody—I went back, and found the prosecutor, took him into the cab, and then I got on the box—while I was going along I asked Henry where he got the prosecutor—he said he took him in Aldgate, drove him to Finsbury, then to the Lock and Key, back to Aldgate, then to the City-road

and the Vinegar-ground—I asked if he had paid him his fare—he said not—I asked why he put him down there—he said he did not know—I asked who would pay him his fare—he said he should look to the girls for it, that the prosecutor took the girls in at the City-road—I searched him at the station, and found on him 9s. 4 1/4 d.—I saw the money picked up where the cab stopped—the prisoners were all of them sober—it was an hour and three-quarters before the prosecutor was quite recovered—I found this pocket-book, with the strap broken, 5l. 13s. 6 1/2 d. in it, and a small American coin, on him—on my way to the station I saw a half-crown on the ground—I picked up a half-crown and a halfpenny.
NOT GUILTY .

2505.
WILLIAM OLIVER was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of July, 3 pieces of paper, called pawnbroker's tickets, value 15s. 6d.; the pro
perty of
William Dean his master.

WILLIAM DEAN . I am a silk weaver, and live in Gascoine-place, Bethnal-green—the prisoner used to work where I did—on Saturday night, the 22nd of July, I had three pawnbroker's duplicates safe in a china coffee strainer in my room—one was for a watch pledged for 5s., and the others for a coat for 8s., and two silk handkerchiefs for 2s. 6d.—I got them from Mr. Miller in the Kingsland-road—the prisoner was with me about seven days—he was with me on the Monday after I saw these things safe—he left me about seven o'clock on Tuesday night, and I missed the tickets about a quarter after seven o'clock—I went to stop them, and saw him in the Hackney-road as I came back—the pawnbroker told me something—I saw the prisoner again about half-past eight o'clock peeping round the corner by my house—he saw me and ran away—I ran after him, and a policeman stopped him.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You did not wish to prosecute? A. No; I have not said if the pawnbroker would give me back my pledges I would not prosecute.

FRANCIS LEATHERS . I am assistant to Thomas Miller, a pawnbroker in the Kingsland-road—these things were pawned by the prosecutor and his wife—on Tuesday the 25th of July the prisoner brought two tickets of a watch and a coat—he said he wanted more on them—I sent for the things down and looked at them and refused to give him more—the witness came and I told him.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you sure the prisoner is the man? A. Yes.
ABRAHAM GUNTON (police-constable.) I took the prisoner—he said he threw the tickets away,

GUILTY. Aged 21.—Recommended to Mercy. —
Confined One Month.

2506.
JULIA SIMMONDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of August, 1 breast-pin, value 5s., the goods of
Edward Roach, from his person.

EDWARD ROACH . I live in Old North-street, Red Lion-square. About one in the morning of the 25th of August I was in Falcon-street—the pri
soner caught hold of me by the coat and wished me to give her something—I desired her to go away, and went into the road to avoid her—I left her, and as I passed round into Aldersgate-street I put my hand on my breast and my pin was gone—it was there a quarter of an hour before—I had stopped with no one else—as I turned I saw a policeman—he went and took her—this is my pin.
Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. I suppose you were perfectly sober? A. Yes—I did not stand with her one minute—I had not promised her 2s. or 2s. 6d., or any sum—I told her to go away.

JAMES PARKER (City police-constable, No. 257.) About one o'clock on this morning I was passing Falcon-street—I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor—the prosecutor was putting out his hand, telling her to keep away from him—he crossed the street, and crossed again, telling her to keep off-—she went towards Goswell-street, and the prosecutor towards the Post-office—I told her if I saw her do that again I would take her up—the prosecutor then spoke to me—I went and spoke to the prisoner about the pin—she was in the act of taking it from her shawl—as soon as she found I felt it, she said, "Here it is"—gbe begged and prayed he would not prosecute her.

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Three Months.

2507.
WILLIAM HOWELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 purse, value 2s. 6d.; 4 sovereigns, and 2 shillings; the property of
Selina Elizabeth Nicholls, from her person.

SELINA ELIZABETH NICHOLLS . I am a widow, and live in Hart-street, Covent-garden. On the 18th of August, about one o'clock, I was in James-street, Covent-garden—I crossed from Long-acre—I was going into my father's house—a person named Jordan was going in just after, and told me something—I felt in my right-side pocket, and missed my purse, containing four sove
reigns and a half-crown—it was safe at nine o'clock in the morning—I had not used it in the mean time—I have not seen it since.

NAOMI JORDAN . I am ten years old, and live in Henrietta-street. About half-past twelve o'clock, on the 18th of August, I was in Long-acre—I saw the prisoner and three men behind the prosecutrix—a man in a white hat put his hand into the prosecutrix's pocket, and took a purse out—the prisoner, took it from him, and put it into his side coat-pocket—he then walked fast up Hart-street, as if he was going to Bow-street—I went into the shop, and laid to the prosecutrix, "You have lost your purse"—she said, "No, I have not got my pocket on"—she felt, and said she had got her pocket on, and had lost her purse

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Which way Were you coming? A. From St. Martin's-lane—I saw the three men for about five minutes—the one in the white hat said to the others, "You two go on the other side of the way, I can do it"—he took it, put up his finger, and called them over to him, and then they all went away—I am sure the prisoner was one—I saw him again at Bow-street about half an hour after.

WILLIAM HALL . I am a green-grocer, and live in Kmg-sireet, Long-acre. On this day 1 saw five persons about together in James-street—I had seen them frequently before—the prisoner was one of them—I saw something taken from the prosecutrix's pocket by one of them, and given to one of the others, I do not know which of them—they were all close together.

Cross-examined. Q. When the prosecutrix's pocket was picked were they all five together? A. No, only three one on one side, and two on the other—the three were all close together till after the pocket was picked—I cannot be mistaken—I saw the prisoner at Bow-street, and did not know him at first—when I saw his hat on, the second time I did know him—I was called to look two or three times, and said I did not think he was one of them, for some time—we all went out of the office together, and in a quarter of an hour after I said I thought I knew him—I am quite sure I am right about the five men being on one side of the way, three on one side of the lady, and two on the other—the Magistrate did not tell me I was committing perjury, that I recollect—I had some doubt of the prisoner till I saw him with a hat on.
GEORGE ANDERSON (police-constable C 85.) I received information, and
apprehended the prisoner in Covent-garden market—there was another man with him—he came out of James-street, and crossed into the market.
Cross-examined. Q. Who gave you information? A. The foreman to the prosecutrix's father—the prisoner had this coat on his arm—he was dressed just as he is now—2s. 2 1/2 d. was found on him.
NOT GUILTY .

2508.
JAMES FLIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Aug., 25 pieces of leather called boot half fronts, value 1l. 5s., the goods of
Samuel Johnson; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

2509.
WILLIAM LEE was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of Feb., 1 truck, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Walter Walker.

FREDERICK CLEVELAND . In Feb. last I was in the service of Walter Walker, a porter, in Rathbone-place, Oxford-street—he lets out trucks. The prisoner came to hire a truck for an hour or an hour and a half, and said he was going to Somers-town—I let him one at 3d. an hour—he took it away, and did not bring it back—I did not see him again till last Friday at Bow-street.
Prisoner. You have known me for many years. Witness. Yes, and know no harm of you.

WALTER WALKER . I am a porter, and live in Rathbone-place. The pri
soner has hired trucks of me by the hour—I do not recollect this truck being let to him—I found I had one less—I never got it back again.
Prisoner. I took it back at eleven o'clock at night—at Bow-street he said, "You left it in the street,"—you were drunk, and did not know what became of it.
Prisoner's Defence. There were more trucks there; I took the worst.
GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. — Confined
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
2510.
CAROLINE COX was indicted
for stealing, on the 1st of Aug., 1 frock, value 4s.; 2 shawls, 1l. 8s.; 3 paintings, 1l.; 2 shifts, 10s.; 1 printed book, 12s.; 1 book, 1l.; 1 box, 1s.; 1 toilet cover, 3s.; 1 gown, 6d.; 1 bonnet, 6d.; 1 collar, 2s.; 3 handkerchiefs, 6s.; 6 shillings, 4 sixpences, and 4 groats; the property of
Sarah Dryden: and 1 coat, 2l.; 1 sheet, 6s.; and 1 shirt, 4s.; the goods of
James Dryden, her master.

SARAH DRYDEN . I am the daughter of James Dryden. The prisoner was in my father's service—when I came home I missed a quantity of things—the prisoner's sister gave a quantity of duplicates to my father, and he gave them to me—these are my things and my father's—he is ill.

WILLIAM COTTER . I am assistant to Francis Ogleby, a pawnbroker, in High-street, Poplar. I produce a frock pawned for 2s. by a girl, who gave the name of Church—this is the duplicate of it—it was not pawned by the prisoner.
GEORGE WOODFORD . I am assistant to Mr. Hawkins, a pawnbroker, in Catherine-street, Limehouse. I produce a sheet.
HENRY JEROME . I am a pawnbroker. I produce a shawl pawned for 3s. and a shirt for 9d. by the prisoner—these are the duplicates I gave her.
Prisoner's Defence. I gave the duplicates of all these things to Mr. Dryden—he said if I did so he would get the things out.

GUILTY. Aged 17.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

2511.
ANN HEWITT and
SARAH BENNETT were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 24th of Aug., 1 petticoat, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Robert Watt; and that Hewitt hadbefore been convicted of felony; to which

BENNETT pleaded
GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

MARIA STEVENS . I live in Clerkenwell. On the 24th of Aug. I was passing the prosecutor's in Exmouth-street, and I saw the prisoners together—I saw Hewitt take a petticoat from the side of the rail at the side of the shop, and put it under her shawl—they both walked away—I gave informa
tion—they were taken, and the petticoat found on them.
Hewitt. Q. Did you not say at first it was Bennett took it, and afterwards say it was me? A. No.

JAMES HARMAN . I live with Robert Watt, in Exmouth-street. I received information, and ran after the prisoners—when I got close to them Hewitt took the petticoat from under her shawl, and threw it in at a door way—this is my master's.

RICHARD BYRNE (police-constable E 116.) I produce a certificate of Hew
itt's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the pri
soner is the person.

HEWITT—
GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.

2512.
RICHARD WEST was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of Feb., 7 pairs of trowsers, value 15s.; and 2 waistcoats, 5s.; the goods of
Fanny Payne.

FANNY PAYNE . I am a widow, and live in John's-row, St. Luke's. About one o'clock, on the 28th of Feb., I gave the prisoner seven pairs of trowsers and two waistcoats to pawn for me—he did not come back—I have never seen either them, or the money since.
Prisoner's Defence. I got a drop of drink and lost them.

GUILTY . Aged 66.—
Confined Nine Months.

2513.
HENRY DETMAR was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Aug., 1 waistcoat, value 9s., the goods of
George Stewart; also,
on the 23rd of Aug., 2 shirts, 6s., the goods of
Lanceman Webster; to both which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2514.
ELIZA NIGHTINGALE BROWN was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of June, 4 blankets, value 2l.; 2 sheets, 14s.; 1 snuff-box, 6d.; and 1 printed book, 1d.; the goods of
John Forrester, her master: and
ELIZA BASSETT BROWN
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen.

JOHN FORRESTER . I live in Compton-street. The prisoner Nightingale worked for me—I missed a sheet from the bed on which she slept, and the blanket from the bed underneath—I asked her where they were—she made no reply—I pressed for an answer, and then she said she took them to her mother's to wash.

Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. Did you say it would be better to tell the truth? A. No—she was never required to wash the bedding of her own bed—this snuff-box and book are mine—they are worth about 7d.
THOMAS HOOKER . I am a pawnbroker—I produce a sheet and blanket—I took in the blanket of Bassett Brown.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. She had pawned a great number of things, and taken them out? A. Yes—I have known her about twelve months.

ROBERT ADAMS (police-constable E 109.) I took Nightingale Brown, and found in her box the snuff-box and book—I went to Elizabeth Bassett Brown, her mother next morning, and said I came for the blanket and sheet her daughter had sent to be washed—she said she had not got them—I said, "Where are they?"—she said they were pledged—she went up stairs, and came down with these two tickets and some others—she said she hoped her daughter had not stolen them—I said, "You knew they were not yours"—she said, "Yes—I knew they were stolen."
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How long was it before she said they were stolen? A. It might have been ten minutes.
COURT. Q. May she not have said, "I did not know they were stolen?" A. No, she said the other.
Cross-examined by MR. DOWLING. Q. Was Nightingale Brown's box locked? A. No.
NOT GUILTY .

2515.
WILLIAM HENRY HENLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 2 pairs of trowsers, value 2s. 6d.; and one gown, 7s. 6d.; the goods of
William Henly.

WILLIAM HENLY . The prisoner is my son; he had run away from home—I missed a pair of his trowsers—I then went to town, and could not find him—when I returned, his mother missed this gown and two pairs of trowsers—these now produced are mine—I found a duplicate on the prisoner, which led me to the pawnbroker's.
HENRY EDWARD BONHAM . I produce this gown—I took it in pledge of a woman—this is the duplicate I gave for it.
Prisoner. I am very sorry for it.

2516.
MARGARET REARDON was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 1 knife, value 1s., and 1 fork, 6d.; the property of
John Draper, her master.
JOHN DRAPER . I keep the Globe public-house—the prisoner was in my service—I missed a knife and fork—I believe these to be mine—there is a stain on the handle—it is difficult to say they are mine.
WILLIAM JOHN BIRD . The prisoner brought this knife and fork to me—I gave her 4d. for them.
Prisoner. I have had them these four years.
NOT GUILTY .

2517.
GEORGE ATHERTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 3 1/2 lbs. of brass, value, 1s.; the goods of
Asher Prior, his master.

GEORGE MOORE . I am foreman to Asher Prior, an ironmonger—the pri
soner was his errand boy—as he was going by on the 14th of Aug., I called him and asked him why he did not look at me—I opened his coat and saw two pieces of brass, one in each pocket, rolled up.

GEORGE KNOX . I am apprentice to the prosecutor—these pieces of brass are my master's—I had seen them safe about a week before Moore found them in the prisoner's pocket, in the store-room under the shop.

GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy —
Confined Nine Days.

2518.
ELIZABETH DUKES was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of June, 2 shirts, value 4s., and 1 handkerchief, 2s.; the goods of
James Price, her master.

HARRIET PRICE . I am the wife of James Price—the prisoner was em
ployed occasionally, by me, as a char-woman—I accompanied the officers to the shop of Mr. King, a pawnbroker, in Holborn—I saw two shirts and a
handkerchief—one of them I swear to; the other, to the best of my belief, is mine.
JOHN CLARIDGE . I am in the service of Mr. King, of Holborn—these shirts and handkerchief were pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner. I did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Two Months.

2519.
JAMES WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of Aug., 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
Edward Herbert Kenney, from his person.

EDWARD HERBERT KENNET . I live in Sussex-street, Hyde Park—about two o'clock, on the 24th of Aug., I was in St. James's Park—Wright called to me, he had my handkerchief—I had put it in my pocket in the morning, and had not used it.
JOHN WRIGHT (police-constable 128 E.) I was on doty in the Park, and saw the prisoner take the handkerchief from the prosecutor's pocket—I collared him and found these other handkerchiefs on him.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

2520.
GEORGE NICHOLSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of August, 1 jacket, value 1l.; the goods of
Charles Buckman.

CHARLES BUCKMAN . I am a sailor, and live in Hoxton Old-town. On the 15th of August I left my jacket on the table where I lodged—I missed it the same evening—I went to the Britannia saloon in search of the prisoner the next day, and accused him of stealing it—he said if I would keep him from trouble and out of the policeman's hand, he would make the jacket right to me, and told me to go further up the street that the crowd should not know what was the matter—I walked up about half a mile, then stopped, and asked him about the jacket—he began at high words—the constable came up and asked what was the matter—he said there was nothing the matter—he then told me if I went up a little further he would tell me all—the jacket has never been found—after I gave him into the hands of the police he told something.

HARRIET TAYLOR . The prisoner came into my room and asked if the prosecutor, who is my brother, was at home—I said no—he took a book and began to read—I went into the next room—he was in the room two hoars—I afterwards heard him go—I then went into the room and missed the jacket off the table—there was no one in the room but my little sister—if any one else had come in I should have heard them.

LOUISA TAYLOR . I remember the prisoner coming on the 15th of August—he was there two hours—I went out of the room for two minutes, and when I came back the jacket was gone—I had put the book which I had been reading, on the jacket on the table—the book was still left—this was the prosecutor's jacket.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

2521.
THOMAS JAMES GREEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 1 shoe, value 2s.; and one stocking, value 8d.; the goods of
Wil
liam Clark.

WILLIAM CLARK . I live with my father, James Clark—I Im in a school—my father does not find my shoes and stockings—on the 19th of August I took off my stocking and shoe on Bow Common—I put them down to go and play—the prisoner ran away with them—I ran after him—he got away, and I told the policeman—I am sure he is the boy—I had not known him before.

GEORGE OSBORNE (police-constable K. 129) Clark came to me crying—I ran and took the prisoner—ho said, "I have not got it, another boy ran away with it"—I took him back to the prosecutor, who said he was positive he was the boy.
Prisoner's Defence. A boy with me took them, and I ran away.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Two Months.

2522.
MARY MURRAY was indicted
for stealing, on thr 29th of July, 2 petticoats, value 6s.; 2 shifts, 1s. 3d.; and 3 gowns; the goods of
Henry Phillips Arnold, from the person of
William Arnold.

ELIZABETH ARNOLD . I am the wife of Henry Phillips Arnold. On the 29th of July I sent a basket, containing two petticoats, three gowns, and two shifts, by my little boy, to Lamb's Conduit-street—he brought the basket back without the linen—I have not found the things.

WILLIAM ARNOLD . On the 29th of July my mother sent me with a basket of clothes—as I was going along the prisoner stopped me, and said she was left in care of the house, and I was to leave them with her—in consequence of that I went into a house, and left them there—I am quite sure she is the woman.
HENRY ARNOLD . I am brother of William Arnold—the prisoner is the woman that took the things.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in Lamb's Conduit-street—some boys were tormenting me—I met a woman and asked where she was going to—she said to No. 5—I took the child to Museum-street.

GUILTY .* Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.
There were two other indictments against the prisoner.

2523.
JOHN LUMSDEN and
ALFRED BASHFORD were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July, 1 watch, value 1l. 10s.; 1 scarf, 2s. 6d.; 1 necklace, 1s.; 1 sovereign; and 23 shillings; the property of
Thomas Bailey.

ELIZABETH BAILEY . On the 10th of July the prisoners came to my house about ten o'clock—Bashford was a stranger—they sat in the kitchen a bit—a, man named Howe came to mend a mantel-piece—Lumsden said, "Mrs. Bailey, send the old man out for some beer"—I said, "There is no cause to spend your money"—he would persist in it, and put sixpence, a penny, and two halfpence in my hand—I sent Howe for the beer, and went up and let him in—I showed them all over the house, and while Lumsden kept me talking in the kitchen, Bashford bolted with my husband's watch, which I had seen safe at twelve o'clock over the fire-place—I did not miss it till I sat down to dinner—this is it—it is No. 6394.
Lumsden. I had a friend with me, but it was not Bashford. Witness. I am convinced it was Bashford.

HENRY BILSON . I am assistant to Mr. Barker, a pawnbroker, in Hounds-ditch—this watch was pledged by Bashford on the 10th of July—I think about two or three o'clock—I live five miles from the prosecutrix.

WILLIAM ANGUS . I am a stonemason, and live in Essex-street, Com
mercial-road. I know the prisoners—on the 7th of July I saw them in the Mile-end-road—I played at skittles with them at the Maid and Magpie in Stepney, but I never saw them speak to each other—I believe they came in company—I owed Lumsden 1s.—he came to me in the Star and Garter for it, and asked if I was going to the Prince of Wales, and there I saw Bashford.

HENRY FRANCES (police-constable N 227.) I went after Lumsden—I told him I took him on suspicion of stealing Mrs. Bailey's watch—on the way to the Court, next day, he asked if she missed anything—I said, "No"—I took

Bashford next day—he said he came from Lee, in Kent—I found this dupli
cate on him—I heard both say they never saw each other before.
(Lumsden received a good character.)

BASHFORD—
GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

LUMSDEN—
GUILTY . Aged 28.

2524.
JOHN LUMSDEN was again indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of June, 2 marble chimney-pieces, value 14l. 14s., the goods of
James Rogers, and another.

JOHN CHRISTIE . I live in Lower Queen-street, Rotherhithe, and am in partnership with James Rogers. On the 13th of June I missed two chim
ney pieces from Princes-street, Rotherhithe—they were worth fourteen guineas—these are them.

JOSEPH BENJAMIN AVILA . I am a pawnbroker, and live in the Mile End-road. These two chimney-pieces were pawned on the 17th of Aug., by the prisoner, for 2l.—I have no doubt about it—I gave the money to him.

Prisoner. I was in Whitechapel-road—Jackson called me, and asked me to lend him a hand to shove the truck down to the turnpike, and he would stand two or three pots of beer—I said, "What have you got?" he said, "Marble chimney-pieces to pawn, at Mrs. Avila's"—I lent him a hand, and he pawned them.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2525.
MARGARET ALLEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Aug., 5 flat-irons, value 5s.; 1 tea-kettle, 9s.; 1 purse, 6d.; 7 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign, the property of
Sophia Woodden, her mistress.

SOPHIA WOODDEN . The prisoner lived with me for a month as a weekly servant. On the 12th of Aug. I put my purse behind my pillow—it con
tained seven sovereigns and a half—I missed them after breakfast next morning—she was very poor indeed when she came to me—I lent her 1s. on the Friday to buy a second-hand pair of shoes, as all her shoes were gone.

JAMES BRADLEY (police-constable B 134.) I took the prisoner on the Friday following the robbery, and asked if she had got any money—she said she had none—she had a bonnet-box at her lodging, in Welborough-place, Chelsea—I found two boxes there, filled with good articles, which appeared to have been released from pawn, and in the large chest which she had not told me of, I found four sovereigns.

ELIZABETH KNOWLES . The prisoner came to lodge with me at Mrs. Foley's—I did not see her bring the boxes—I did not say that the boxes searched by the policeman, were brought there by her—I believe them to be hers.

ELIZABETH ARNOLD . I am searcher at the station. The prisoner told me the had got no money—I found on her 9s. 2d.—she asked me what would be done with her—I said I did not know—she said seven sovereigns and a half of the old lady's were lost, but they would not find the purse—if they went to her lodging they would find some money.

MARY ANN GRAHAM . I was at Mr. Perkins's, the pawnbroker's, on the 16th of Aug.—I saw the prisoner there—she gave some tickets in—I saw her change a sovereign, and take two parcels out, and then I saw her give an
other sovereign.
Prisoner. I had but one sovereign in my hand. Witness. You changed one, and when I came back you changed another—I said, "You have made a good harvest to leave the wash-tub."
Prisoner's Defence. I got four sovereigns at a raffle, and the rest I worked
hard for; on the Tuesday morning the prosecutrix sent me to the butcher's, to see if she had left her purse there.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined One Year.

2526.
DENNIS M'CARTHY was indicted
for receiving, on the 15th of Aug., 6 balls of hemp, value 2s.; 1/4 lb. weight of nails, 2d.; 3 leather backs for boots, 2s.; 2 leather fronts for shoes, 1s.; and 1lb. weight of leather, 8d.; the goods of
Henry Snead, of a certain ill-disposed person, well knowing them to be stolen.

WILLIAM FREEMAN . I am shopman to Mr. Henry Snead, and live in Tot
hill-street, Westminster—Took has been in the service—about ten o'clock on the 15th of August, I found a pair of soles in his trowsers when he was going home—I went with him to a house in Bedfordbury—the prisoner lives there—he opened the door—I went into a room on the first floor—the prisoner said it was his room—it was searched, and six balls of hemp, five soles, some nails, three boot-backs, and some other things found—I believe them to be my master's, but would not swear to them—the policeman continued the search, and was tying up these things—the prisoner said, "You have no oc
casion to search any further, the devil a farthing's worth more is there in the place than what you have got"—I never saw him at my master's.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You only know these from circumstances? A. Yes—I cannot say when I had seen them safe—8d. is not much under the value of the soles to sell, but if I went to buy them, I should have to pay 14d. or 16d. for them.

ROBERT TOOK . I am thirteen years old. I have been in the prosecutor's service—the prisoner met me one day in New-street, Covent-garden—he said, "Can you get me a bit of leather to mend my shoes with?"—I said, "I will get you a bit if I can"—he said, "Don't let any one see you"—next day I gave him a pair of soles—he gave me 8d. for them—I then brought him a half sole—he gave me 4d. for it, and said, "Try to bring me some more if you can"—I did so, and he gave me 6d.—he repeatedly told me to get in re—all these things are Mr. Snead's property.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he refuse to take goods of you? A. No—I met him by the Boccius lamp—he kept a stall there—he knew my father was a shoemaker, and lived up a court there.
WILLIAM CHAPLEN (police-constable B 118.) I found these things in the room.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Confined One Year.

2527.
WILLIAM NOCK was indicted
for embezzlement.

WILLIAM PRITCHARD . I live in High-street, Poplar—the prisoner was my shopman—when he sold things he ought to account to me directly, and enter it in a book—I was in the shop on the 21st of Aug.—he left about eight o'clock that morning—there is no entry of 7s. 6d. that day—nor have I had it.

Prisoner. I entered his service not on a salary, but to have ten per cent on the profits, which made me consider myself a sort of partner—and he agreed I should take the ten per cent, every week—a few weeks after I said I did not want it every week, and he authorized me, if I wanted money to take it, and put it down in the book. Witness. He went away directly he bad re
ceived this—he came back on the Wednesday evening drunk—I said, "About this 7s. 6d."—he said, "It is all right, I always keep these clear"—I did not give him authority to take money—I had given him notice to leave, but his time had not expired.
WILLIAM SHAW . I went to the prosecutor's shop, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning of the 21st of August—I bought something and paid the prisoner 7s. 6d.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

2528.
THOMAS CANEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of De
cember, 7 printed books, value 14s., the goods of
Elizabeth Tomlin.

ELIZABETH TOMLIN . I keep a circulating library in Merlin-place, Clerken
well—the prisoner came to me on the 10th of Dec, and had seven volumes.

Cross-examined by MR. JONES. Q. Is Mrs. Scriven your sister? A. Yes—they are my books, and the premises are hers—I am single—I never saw the prisoner before that day—persons pay according to the time they keep the books—there was no time mentioned to return them that I recollect.

COURT. Q. What is the usual time? A. A week or a fortnight—we lend them for six or seven months, if they are going to take them into the country—he never told me they were for the country—they have not been returned.
JANE SCRIVEN . The prisoner came for. the books on the 10th of Dec.—I am sure he is the man.
ANN GUNN . I am the wife of Mr. Gunn—I remember seeing the prisoner that day—I have no doubt about of him.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. Yes, two or three times in Clerken well.
JURY to ELIZABETH TOMLIN. In what name did he take the books? A. Mr. Scott—there was no deposit paid for them.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

2529.
FERDINAND VALENTINE was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of May, 1 guitar, value 10s.; 3 time-pieces, 3l.; 4 handkerchiefs, 8s.; 3 brushes, 6s.; 1 pair of scissors, 1s.; 2 stocks, 3s.; 1 pair of drawers, 1s.; 3 accordions, 1l. 10s.; 2 copper-plates, 1l.; 2 pearl fish, 1s.; 3 shaving-cases, 1l.; 2 rules, 1s.; 1 breast-pin, 6s.; 1 shaving-brush, 1s.; 2 waist-coats, 2l. 10s.; 3 pairs of trowsers, 1l. 16s.; 1 ring, 1l.; 2 pattern-books, 2s.; 2 pieces of leather, 1s. 6d.; 1 coat, 2l. 1 fish-slice, 2s., 6d.; 1 pair of tongs, 2s. 6d.; and 2 books, 1l.; the goods of
Henry William Albert, his master.

HENRY WILLIAM ALBERT . In 1841 I carried on business in London, as a merchant—I had offices in Oxford-court, Cannon-street, City. On the 19th of May I left this country—before I left, I engaged the prisoner as my clerk, at 1l. per week—I paid him 2l. the day before I went to France—I was away till August—in the interval some letters passed between me and him—I took a list of every thing I had in my office—I had a trunk in my counting-house, containing waistcoats, trowsers, handkerchiefs, stockings, and a ring, and I left a guitar and time-piece in my private room—I locked the trunk, and put the key into my cash-box, and the key of my cash-box I took with me—the cash-box I put into the office—I did not give the prisoner authority to open the trunk, and take any of the things, or to sell or pawn any—I returned in August, and saw the prisoner—he advised me not to go to my office, as I should be arrested for debt—I saw Duke, who was a friend of mine, and the prisoner together—I left it to them to try to arrange with my creditors—I staid in London a long time without going to my office—the prisoner came to we many times, and said, "You are watched from morning till night, and

You must not come"—I went at last, about six weeks before I had the pri
soner taken—I saw my box three weeks after—it was locked—I asked my landlord to break it open—I found there was nothing left in it—all my other things were gone—I afterwards found the prisoner, and had him taken—the things I lost were worth more than 10l.—I went with a policeman to the pri
soner's house, and there found the key of my trund, and the duplicates and other things.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. What do you deal in? A. I take goods from France—I have no office at clerks now—I had an office in Falcon-square—I paid 6l. a quater for it—I lived there six months—I went from there to Oxford-court—I was there six years—in 1839 I was ruined, and took the benefit of the act—I then gave my name as James Henry Albert—I did not take my oath to the proceedings as Jew—I am a Protestant—I did not give my name as Jacob—when I went away I gave authority to the prisoner to carry on my business in Oxford-court, and left my office in his occupation—I paid him no money except the two weeks' salsry in advance—he was subject to expences on my behalf—I was in constant communication with him when I was at Paris—I know a person named Scalinger—Ihave seen him before with the prisoner—I have not been with him and the prisoner playing at cards—I have not been in friendly communication with the pri
soner since I found this out—I know a Mr. Hill, Mr. Hobler's clerk—I have quarrel with the prisoner—I had a private quarrel at the Eight Bells—it was not about this business.

COURT. Q. Are these razors and other things yours? A. Yes; I did not find the cash-box at all—in it was the key of the trunk and a bill of Emboucheres—I know a person named Sheeler—I sas him many times before I went to Paris—I lost the key of my cash-box at paris—Sheeler was not present when I gave the prisoner the key.
MR. JONES. Q. Was your cash-box like this one? A. Yes; I cannot swear to this being it—(looking at one.)

JOHN GREAVES (police-constable G 46.) I was called on the 3rd of July to take the prisoner—the prosecutor told him it was for robbing him of wearing apparel and other articles—the prisoner made no answer—I went with him to his lodgings in Warwick-place, Whitecross-street, and found two time-pieces, a dressing-case, a gold ring, a pin, and some other things which the prosecutor claimed—the prisoner said nothing—I also found fourteen dupli
cates and a key, which the prosecutor swears to as belonging to his box.
Cross-examined. Q. Were these all about the room? A. Yes; the time-piece was going at the time, over the mantel-piece.

LEONARD WILSON . I am assistant to Mr. Russell, a pawnbroker in Fore-street—nine of these duplicates were given by our house, for a pair of trowsers, three waistcoats, and a stocks, pawned on the 20th of April, 1842; two boots, pawned on the 30th of April; a tea caddy the 4th of June; a Ger
man silver fish slice and tongs on the 13th of June; two accordians on the 18th of June; and a time-piece on the 27th of June; the whole amount is 3l. 15s.—they were pawned by a man—I cannot say who—the prisoner has pleged things, and has renewed tickets.

HENRY WILLIAM ALBERT
re-examined. This is the key of my trunk that I left in my cash-box—these things are all mine—it is possible some of them were taken from my place and pawned before I left—I never gave the pri
soner authority to pledge any of these.
Cross-examined. Q. You swear to the trowsers? A. Yet; theft it no mark on them, hut I have worn them often.

IGNATIUS DROOP . I conduct my aunt's business as a merchant—I know both the prisoner and the prosecutor—I remember the prosecutor going abroad—I lent him some money to go—he said he was going to fetch his cousin—I saw him, just previous to his going, give up the key of his cash-box to the prisoner, and tell him every thing he left in his possession, and to do the same as he did—I had a bill to indorse, and he asked the prisoner to indorse it—I said I had rather have his signature.

MR. JONES. Q. Where do you live? A. In Tower Royal, and I have a country house at Laytonstone—I have been in this country about eight years—I have never been in business for myself—the prosecutor told me that every thing the prisoner did was as if he did it himself—he told me that at Oxford-court—the prisoner was there, and there was a gentleman in his private room, with the door shut—I do not know his name—he went with the prosecutor to Paris—I have seen the key of the cash-box in the prisoner's possession since—I never saw him take the key of the trunk out of the cash-box—I saw him open the cash-box, after the prosecutor was gone, with the key that the prosecutor gave him—I went to him next day, because I forgot two bills of 150l., and he opened the cash-box—I never saw him open the trunk—I do not know any
thing about opening the tea-caddy on the 4th of June—the prisoner was in my aunt's service for some months as clerk—I took him about six months after the prosecutor went—our former clerk's name was Smith—he died—I saw the prosecutor when he returned in August, and showed him the door of our office, and forbad him to come—I told him there was a person named Mullens, whom he owed money to, would take out a writ against him—I did not tell him, if he went to his office in Oxford-court, he would be arrested by a sheriff's officer—I swear that I did not tell him there was a sheriff's officer watching for him, or that it would not be safe for him to go to his office—I did not tell the prosecutor to wait patiently till bis affairs came round—he did not say he would go to bis creditors and state to them what goods he had sent from Paris to the prisoner, and what property he had left at hit office—he laid he should resign himself and his property to his creditors—I did not say I hoped he would not act unkindly by me, at he knew the business was my aunt's, and not mine—I did not tell him I would provide him with money to go to Jersey, and set up business there—I said, "I don't know what you do here; you owe me a deal of money; if you were worth anything they would take you"—he told me he would go abroad, but he did not—I have been to the prisoner's lodgings once, just to see where he lives—I have not received from him any of the prosecutor's property—the property which I re
ceived from him belonged to me—it was property which the prosecutor had bought, and I had accepted bills and paid them honestly—it was bought of a merchant at Vienna—I received property of the prisoner after the prosecutor left England—it was property which the prosecutor had bought and paid for.
MR. WILDE. Q. What does he owe you now? A. 311l.—I am not a man of substance—I have been in business seven years and a half.

JOSEPH SULLINOTON . I am a fancy trimming-maker. When the prosecu
tor returned from Paris I went to meet him, as the prisoner had no money—he begged of me to do so; and as at that time of year we were very slack in business, I went to Dover—I met the prosecutor—the prisoner went first, and they came into the public-house where I was—they kept on quarrelling—I said, "I don't like to hear this, the landlord will turn us out"—the

prosecutor complained of the prisoner leaving the office—I said, "what was he to do; you left him 2l."—he said, "That is right"—I said, "How could he keep on the office? you sent him letters and things; how could he keep on?"—he said, "Did I not leave him the trunk full of things? if he wanted he could have made money"—the prisoner said, "Of course I did; but what of that? that was not enough to keep me and pay letters and all and then I left the office"—I called at the prisoner's room on a Sunday morn
ning, and saw Mr. Hill there—I was not there above two minutes when the pro
secutor came in—Hill began some conversation, and the prisoner said, "You had better go home to dinner"—I looked up, and said, "I don't think your clock is right"—Mrs. Valentine said, "It is not right, it was not wound up"—the prisoner took out his watch and said, "It is not right."

MR. JONES. Q. Where do you carry on business? A. In Brudenell-place, New North-road—this is my first quarter—I have got the lease of the house—I came from Shoreditch—I have been six years in this country—I have known the prisoner three or four years—he has never been in my service—he is no relation of mine—when I met the prosecutor at Dover, I did not tell him it was not safe for him to go to his counting-house—I went to Dover because the prisoner had a letter from the prosecutor to meet him—I paid the expenses—I went down with the prisoner—I said, "I will pay my expenses, but you must pay for yourself "—he said, "Mr. Albert will pay you again,"but he has not—I left them at Dover—I did not hear the prisoner tell the prose
cutor it would not be safe to come to London—Valentine said, "What did you write for me to come here? you might as well have left me at home"—I then asked what was the matter, and he said the prisoner had left the office, which he has no business to do—he blowed him up for not putting on his best clothes—the prisoner said, "Don't you know I have pledged everything you left at home; but was that sufficient?"—the prosecutor said he should have managed somehow to have kept the office open.

FRANCIS HILL . I am an attorney's clerk, and have been an attorney—I have been employed by the prisoner to negociate some misunderstandings between him and the prosecutor—I had instructions to meet the prosecutor at the latter end of Feb. or beginning of March—I went to his lodgings, and saw him—he did not expect me—we had some conversation—he appointed for me to come on the following morning at a quarter before nine o'clock—I went—he said, "What have you to say?"—I said, "I think you had better settle it; you claim money of him, and he does of you; if you will meet him at Oxford-court to-morrow, and give up some letters, all will be settled"—he appointed for me to call again, and I did—he was gone out—I told him the prisoner was willing to waive his claim to his salary, if he would give up his documents and the receipt for his goods.

MR. JONES. Q. For whom did you act? A. As a friend—the prisoner had the goods either in his possession or under his control—he did not tell me he had pawned some—I did not tell the prosecutor he had pawned any—the prosecutor was looking at a list of the articles when I called on Sunday morning—he said, "These are the things that I left"—I said, "You are aware that he parted with some"—he said, "I don't know; all I want is my things back."
MR. WILDE. Q. Have you been to the prisoner's lodgings, and seen the clock over the mantel-piece? A. Yes—the prosecutor has been there—and seen the trowsers and things about.
—COLLINS. Albert rented an office of me—he went abroad in May—the prisoner discontinued his attendance there about July, at my request—I
found there was no rent, and the persons were coming for money—he was regular in his attendance till about a fortnight before he left—I broke open the trunk at the prosecutor's request.
MR. WILDE. Q. Did the prisoner conduct himself with propriety? A. Yes, to me—the whole of the furniture was mine.

GUILTY. Aged 40.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Six Months.

2530.
JOHN HODDER was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of Aug., 1 saw, value 5s. 6d.; the goods of
Edward Hardy.

EDWARD HARDY . I live with my father, Edward Hardy. This saw was safe about six o'clock last Tuesday evening, in Hoxton market—I missed it, and ran after the prisoner, and took him with the saw on his arm, in Long
alley.

WILLIAM ANDREW FERGUSON (police-constable G 181.) A little before seven o'clock I saw a crowd—I went up—the prisoner said, "You are not wanted, it is only a lark "—the prosecutor gave him in cjiarge—in going along he said he bought it for 1s.
Prisoner's Defence. A lad said did I want to bay a saw? I said I had only 1s. I bought it for 1s.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

2531.
JAMES SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of Aug., 1 watch, value 5l.; 1 seal, 10s.; and 1 key, 10s.; the goods of
Richard Thomas Scott.

CHARLOTTE SCOTT . I am the wife of Richard Thomas Scott, and live in High-street, Poplar. About a quarter to twelve o'clock, on the 18th of Aug., I left the parlour to speak to my husband—I left a watch hanging on a nail over the chimney-piece—I was away about two minutes—when I returned the watch was gone—the prisoner was in the parlour—I asked what he wanted—he said he had paper to sell—no one could have taken it but him—he was taken in about five minutes—there were two boys with him.
Prisoner's Defence. I went with some paper; there was no one there, so I went out.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

2532.
HARRIET EDMONDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Aug., 30 yards of merino, value 1l. 4s.; the goods of
Richard Cole Baker and another.

JAMES FERGUSON . I am in the service of Richard Cole Baker and another, linen-drapers, Leather-lane. I saw the prisoner and another come into the shop—this merino was on a pile in the shop—the other one took it, and gave it to the prisoner, who put it under her shawl, and went off—I ran out, and brought her back with it.
Prisoner's Defence. The young woman asked me to carry it, and she would give me a trifle.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Two Months.

2533.
ANN SCOTT was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of July, 1 jacket, value 1l.; 1 handkerchief, 2s.; 1 printed book, 6d.; 1 tobacco-box, 2d.; and 1 order for the payment of 4l.; the property of
William Thompson: and
JOHN JONES
for feloniously receiving 1 jacket; and
SUSAN MASON
for feloniously receiving 1 handkerchief, 1 printed book, 1 tobacco-box, and an order for the payment of 4l., part of the said property; well knowing the same to have been stolen, against the Statute, &c.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2534.
ELLEN COTTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of Aug., 2 pence and 7 halfpence; the monies of
George Holborow, her master.

GEORGE HOLBOROW . I live in Clare-street, Clare-market—the prisoner was in my service. On the morning of the 18th of Aug., at six o'clock I watched her going to the water-closet—I had counted my money the previous night, and left 4s. in copper in the till—part of it was marked—I sent for an officer, and she was searched, but nothing found on her—we found, hidden behind a tub in the water-closet, two pence and seven halfpence, which were marked.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. How long had she been in your ser
vice? A. About two months—I marked this money myself on the previous evening, at eleven o'clock—I have two young men, but they were in bed at the time—I had been to the water-closet myself before I called a policeman—I looked for it then, but could not find it.

JAMES HART . I live servant two doors from the prosecutor. The pri
soner was constantly bringing in coppers to me to change for silver—I thought it was not right, and told the prosecutor.
LEE VINER (police-constable F 143.) I found two pence and seven half-pence in the water-closet marked.
NOT GUILTY .

2535.
ELLEN COTTON was again indicted
for stealing on the 1st of Aug., 3 handkerchiefs, value 3s.; 1 petticoat, 1s.; 1 yard of silk, 3s.; 1/2 yard of net, 3s.; 1 cap, 5s.; 2 pairs of gloves, 1s.; and 1 gown, 3s.; the goods of
Martha Jane Taylor.

MARTHA JANE TAYLOR . I am niece to George Holborow. I searched the prisoner's box—no one was with me—I found three handkerchiefs, a pet
ticoat, and some other things—they were mine—I had not given them to her or authorised her to take them.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Are you single? A. Yes—this pro
perty was kept in various places—a room in the attic was occupied by the prisoner, the floor above mine—there were a set of drawers in her bed-room—they were used by her—the bottom drawers had some of our bed furniture in it—I told her she might have the use of the middle drawer—this petticoat is mine—it has no mark on it—I have worn it—one of these handkerchiefs is marked with ink, and my night cap is marked with three letters—the prisoner was taken between six and seven o'clock—I went to her box between ten and eleven.
COURT. Q. Who had access to her room? A. No one that I know of—the two boys never went.
LEE VINER . I searched the box for the coppers, and found this purse in it; and this pincushion in a locked box, which the prisoner gave me the key of.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Three Months.

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Edward Bullock, Esq.

div1.p:
2536.
RICHARD VINCER was indicted
for embezzlement.

JAMES BLYTHE BRUNTON . I live, in Cheyne-walk, Chelsea, and am a baker. The prisoner was in my service for three weeks—it was his duty to receive money and to account for it either to me, or my daughter, or to the shopwoman—he did not pay me 2l. 0s. 9d. from Mr. Tierney for bread up to the 5th of Aug.

COMFORT TIERNEY . I am the wife of Charles Tierney—we live in Para
dise-row, Chelsea. I had a weekly account with the prosecutor—in this book

the amount for the week ending on the 5th of Aug. is 2l. 0s. 9d.—the pri
soner had latterly been in the habit of bringing the bread, and I paid him that week's account, 2l. 0s. 9d.—it was my usual practice to hand orer this book to him to get Mr. Brunton's receipt to it, but on that occasion I forgot it—the following week, up to the 12th of Aug., the bread amounted to 2l., 0s. 9 1/2 d.—I paid him that on the 12th, and I said, "Why did not you ask me for the book last week to get it receipted, you know I paid you the money?"—he said, "I know you did."
Prisoner. I did not have the money that time. Witness. Yes, I know I paid it you.
ANN GAMMON . I am shopwoman to the prosecutor. The prisoner did not account to me for this 2l. 0s. 9d. as which was owing on the 5th of Aug.

EUPHEMIA BRUNTON . I am the prosecutor's daughter. On the 12th of Aug. the prisoner brought me 2l. 0s. 9 1/2 d. as the amount of Mrs. Tierney's bread—he had handed me this book for the purpose of receipting it—I put my name to the bottom of it, which is the week ending on the 12th of Aug.—I then looked, and saw that the amount of the preceding week, the 5th of Aug., had not been receipted—I rubbed my name out from the bottom, and put it to the preceding week—he has not paid me the amount of the preceding week.
RICHARD BEARD (police-sergeant V 17.) I took the prisoner—he said he had never received the money, or if he had he had paid it to the shop-woman.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not receive it.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Four Months.

2537.
THOMAS BENNETT was indicted
for embezzlement.

THOMAS BROWN . I am an earthenware and glass-dealer, in Rosemary-lane and at Walworth. The prisoner was in my service for four years and a half—it was his duty to account to me for the money he received immediately he received it, if I was at home, if not to my son, or a young man who had the management of the books—on the 6th of June he did not account to me for 5s. received from Westbrook—I cannot call to mind whether I was at home on that day, but I am always there at seven o'clock in the morning, and am generally the last there at night—on the 11th he did not account for 2s. 6d. received from Dowling—on the 21st he did not pay me 10s. from Smith—I recollect that day, and recollect his being on my premises after he had been his journey.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Will you swear you were not out all day? A. No—I was there in the morning, and in the evening—he had a private book of his own in which he used to make entries—he made no entry in my books—he called his account from his own book, and the clerk generally made the entry in my book—my books are not here—he has come in some
times and laid down the money, and been told to go into the cellar to get something.

MR. DOANE. Q. What was the reason for his going into the cellar? A. If he was accounting to me for money—a person came and wanted a brown pan—I should say, "Go and get one," but that would not interrupt his accounting—he would go on with his accounts afterwards—I will swear he did not pay me this money on the 21st of June.
WILLIAM BROWN . I am the prosecutor's son. On the 6th of June, the prisoner did not pay me 5s. from Westbrook—nor 2s. 6d. on the 11th from
Dowling—nor 10s. on the 21st, as received from Smith—he had paid me 10s. as received from Smith at different times—he did not pay me this.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you recollect particular days? A. No—I do not keep the books—if he pays me money, I hand it to my father with a list.
HENRY CHRISTIE . I am the prosecutor's clerk—the prisoner did not account to me for either of these three sums.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you keep the books? A. Yes—I enter the sums which I receive.

SARAH WESTBROOK . I am a widow, and live in Providence-row, Homer
ton. I know the prisoner as bringing goods from Brown—on the 6th of June, I paid him 5s. on account of his master—this is his receipt.
SUSAN DOWLING . I am the wife of John Dowling, who keeps a china shop in Hackney-road. I paid the prisoner 2s. 6d., on the 11th of June for his master.
SUSAN SMITH . My husband lives at Newmarket-terrace, Cambridge-heath. I paid the prisoner 10s. on the 21st of June, on account of his master.
NOT GUILTY .

2538.
THOMAS BENNETT was again indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of Aug., 18 dram glasses, value 12s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Brown his master.

THOMAS BROWN . I deal in glass, and carry on business in Rosemary-lane.
