sage—I walked and stood a yard or so from the door—one of them said, "Stand off, you b—, or I will rip your b—guts out"—I was then within about a yard or a yard and a half of the back door—I told him it was no use, and bid them surrender, they should not pass that way—I was in my police dress—one of them said, "Let us go in and give it the b—" that was not the same voice—one of them then sprang towards me, and I knocked him down with my truncheon—I caught him somewhere by the side of the neck—that was Trenate—I was immediately knocked down by the second party, and received a violent blow over the eye with a life-preserver—I saw it, it was light enough in the yard to see at that time—I fell on Trenate, who I had knocked down, caught him by the collar, and kept hold of him with

my right hand—we were both on the ground together—the other made an attempt to leap over to make his escape, but in the act of doing so I caught him by the leg with my left hand, threw him over, and also secured him by the collar with my left handthat was Huggett—we all three got on our legs again together, and had a violent struggle together—Huggett struck me a second time on the left side of my hat with the life-preserver, which knocked my hat off—Trenate directly said, "Loose me, or I will job your b—eye out"—I had him in my right hand at the time by the collar—he immediately thrust the knife into the side of my eye—from what I could feel of it the knife went apparently under my eye—he also cut my nose afterwards—I was compelled to loose Huggett at that time—I caught Trenate's hand afterwards, but being so weak through loss of blood I could scarcely keep the knife off—he endeavoured to cut me again, and scratched my nose in several places—I saw the knife in his hand, and saw the blade—a constable knocked the knife out of his hand—assistance came up afterwards—53 B came into the yard—Huggett, after making his escape from me, retreated into the house again—Palmer came to me—I told him to go into the house, for there were more in the house—I took Trenate out into Stangate, where I was met I believe by a constable and a brewer's drayman, but I then became insensible—I lost a great deal of blood—I did not loose hold of Trenate at all, during the struggle—I am sure he is the person.

WILLIAM COCKRILL (police-constable L 108.) On the 14th of Aug., about half-past three o'clock in the morning, my attention was called to the prose
cutor's house, by seeing Palmer and Lutchford talking together at the foot of Westminster-bridge—when I got up to the corner of Stangate, Lutchford came towards me, and said he thought there was something wrong at Mr. Mackintosh's, we had better go round to the back, and see if it was safe, which he did—I went up to Palmer—he said something to me—I looked to see if there was any light through the doorway—it was all in darkness—I then went to the side door and heard some whispering and footsteps more from the direction of the bar towards the side entrance, leading to the landing of the stair-caseat that moment Lutchford returned and stated something—I sent him back again—after a short lapse of time I called out to Mr. Mackintosh several times, and as I rang the bell Mr. Mackintosh opened his bed-room window—I told him I thought thieves were in the house—he said, "I thought I heard them a quarter of an hour ago"—the next moment I heard the swing door which leads to the back entrance of the premises pulled back—it works on a pulley, and when the door closes again the pulley makes a noise, which would let me know that the door was closed—about a minute afterwards one of the witnesses came up to the corner of Stangate, and called out to me to send further assistance—I then sent Palmer round to the back of the premises—shortly afterwards I saw Lutchford in the road—he called out to me for assistance, in consequenoe of being stabbed by a knife—I ran to his assistance, and saw Trenate in the act of standing over him, and Lutchford hanging on to the waistband of his trowsers—Trenate had a knife in his hand—Lutchford was on the ground—he turned over twice while I was running from the bridge to where he was lying—I hit Trenate a blow with my fist on his head, and the knife fell down on the left, and he fell to the right of Lutchford—I secured the knife and the prisoner the next mo
ment, before he got up from the ground—at the same moment there was a cry for further assistance at Mr. Mackintosh's—a drayman came up, and being a man I knew well, I asked him to take charge of Trenate, which he did, after I disarmed him—I then returned to the house, knocked at the door, and was admitted—when I got in I was told something by Banister—I

heard that three persons had been seen in the yard—I searched the house, and in the coal-cellar found Jones—this jemmy was found half or three quarters of an hour afterwards—this hat was on his head, and in it was a five-shilling piece and some false curls—I found eleven lucifers on his person at the sta
tion—this house is in the parish of Lambeth.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTONE. Q. St. Mary, Lambeth, is it? A. It is the parish of Lambeth—I do not know whether the parish church is St. Mary—I know it is the parish of Lambeth—this is the knife.

MR. CROUCH. Q. Was it covered with blood? A. Yes, and Trenate's hands also—there are the remains of blood, exactly as I found it—after I apprehended Jones my hat fell off, in consequence of a violent struggle which ensued—he threw me, and the knife fell out—in going down the road I saw Mr. Hinton, a saddler, and I gave the knife to him, as Jones was very violent.

MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Whereabouts was Jones in the coal-cellar? A. At the far side, as far as he could get—he was on his face—he had no appear
ance of being in liquor—I did not smell his breath.

WILLIAM SANDFORD . I am foreman to Mr. Beard, and live in Red Lion-yard, at the foot of Westminster-bridge—it is the yard behind the prosecu
tor's premises—the back gates were open on the night in question, as my master was out—my attention was attracted by the policeman running about—he told me to stand back, which I did, till he had taken two of the pri
soners—he called for a light, and I brought one—I picked up in the yard three spoons, a constable's staff, and some cigars—I gave them to the ser
geant No. 3.

WILLIAM SIMONS (police-sergeant L 3.) I received some articles from Sand
ford, which I produce—I found some cigars, and 1 found a jemmy in the coal-cellar—I dug it out of the coals—I found two german silver forks and a spoon in the bar-parlour, and a pair of plated sugar-tongs—the life-preserver was found on the cellar steps—I tried the jemmy to the bar window, and it fitted it.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLESTON. Q. Where in the cellar did you find the crow-bar? A. Under the coals, nearly in the centre of the cellar—I found it about twenty minutes after I first came up—I did not go into the house the first time—I went through the kitchen, down the stairs, into the coal-cellar—there might be, perhaps, a ton of coals in the cellar.

MATTHEW FRENCH WAGSTAFF . I am surgeon to the police-force—I saw Mr. Mackintosh at the station on the morning, I was sent for—he appeared to have a contused wound on the temple—it was done by some heavy instru
ment—this life-preserver would have done it—there is danger attending a blow on that part—the eye has been discoloured and swollen—it is very slightly so now.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. Was it not such a blow as might have been given by a man's fist? A. I think not—it must have been some heavy instrument—the skin was not broken, but there was that appearance to lead me to suppose it was some heavy instrument—it is possible a violent blow with a fist might do it.

MR. MACKINTOSH re-examined. Q. What was the length of time between your receiving the blow and what took place outside in the yard? A. I be
lieve that must have taken place at the same time—I heard no sound of violence outside—I never heard more than one foot in the house.

TRENATE—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—HUGGETT—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Death Recorded.
(There was another indictment against Trenate and Huggett for wounding the policeman.)

2572.
WILLIAM MONAHAN was indicted
for killing and slaying
Samuel Bennett.
The evidence in this case was similar to that given on the prisoner's former trial—Bennett has since died. (See Eighth Session, page 458.)
NOT GUILTY .

2573.
JAMES ASPERNE was indicted
for a misdemeanor of an indeli
cate nature.
NOT GUILTY .

2574.
THOMAS CONNOLLY was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of August, 1 counterpane, value 5s.; the goods of
Robert Garnham.

SARAH PRIOR . I am barmaid at the Nine Elms public-house, Battersea, kept by Mr. Robert Garnham. On the 8th of August, between one and two o'clock in the day, I saw the prisoner in the yard with the counterpane in a basket—he went out into the road—I gave information, and saw him throw the basket over some palings—I am sure he is the boy—I saw him stopped.

SUSAN GARNHAM . I am the wife of Robert Garnham. I saw the prisoner going off with the basket, and throw it over the fence into a garden—this counterpane, which is mine, was in it—it had been hanging out in the tea-gardens.
HENRY BROOKSON (police-constable V 60.) I received charge of the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was by the side of the railway, and I saw the train coming in—I ran to get a job, and was stopped.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

2575.
MARY M'GAREY was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 1 pair of boots, value 4s.; the goods of
Joshua Powell: and that she had been before convicted of felony; to which she pleaded

GUILTY .** Aged 48.—
Transported Seven Years.

2576.
MATTHEW LEDGER was indicted
for embezzlement; to which he pleaded

2577.
GEORGE TWINE was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 9d.; the goods of
William Ruffell Stevenson.

WILLIAM RUFFELL STEVENSON . I am in the employ of Mr. Russell, a job-master, of Plough-yard, Clapham. On Friday night, the 11th of August, I placed two handkerchiefs and something else on the footboard of a fly in a coach-house in my master's yard—there are large gates, and room for seven or eight carriages to stand—I went to work at half-past six o'clock next morning, and found an old handkerchief which I had left, but I missed the one now produced—I saw it again in possession of the policeman—it is mine—there is about an inch in one corner that has been hemmed, but it is picked out now—I can see the place where it has been hemmed—if it is held up to the light you will see the holes—I will swear to it.

STEPHEN FARMER (police-constable V 154.) On the 12th of August the prisoner passed me in Clapham, about twenty minutes before two o'clock in the morning—I followed him for about 250 yards—when he got to the turning to the back of Mr. Russell's stable I lost sight of him—I afterwards went round and searched, but could not find him—I found the front gates open, which five minutes before I met him were fast.
SAMUEL EASTMAN (police-constable V 132.) I received information from Farmer, and apprehended the prisoner—he had a handkerchief with him like this one, but I could not swear it was this.

WILLIAM EDMAN (police-constable V 179.) I received information, went to the station, and took this handkerchief from the prisoner's hat—he said he bought it in the New-cut—one corner of it has been hemmed for about an inch, but has been now unpicked.
Prisoner's Defence. I had the handkerchief in my hat when I was taken to the station, and I took it to wash myself with before all the policemen, which I should not have done if I had stolen it.
NOT GUILTY .

2578.
WILLIAM HANDCOCK was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of June, 20 paving-stones, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Joseph Sargent and ano
ther, his masters.

JOSEPH SARGENT . I am in partnership with Charles Denton. We em
ployed the prisoner—I did not authorise him to sell any paving-stones—I have seen some stones since—they correspond with those we had at Paradise-street, but I could not swear to them—I never authorised the prisoner to part with them.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. You were directed to take up these stones? A. Yes; we had a contract with the parish of Rotherhithe to take them up, and lay down new ones.

COURT. Q. Were they under your care and custody? A. Yes; we were answerable to carry them to a laystall belonging to the commissioners—they had been in our carts—I had not the care, the custody, or the possession of them.
NOT GUILTY .

2579.
WILLIAM HANDCOCK was again indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of June, 30 paving-stones, value 1l. 13s., the goods of
Joseph Sargent and another, his masters.

JOSEPH SARGENT . I am in partnership with Charles Denton. We under
took to take up the old paving at Rotherhithe, and lay down new—we took up the old ones—we employed the prisoner, but he was not authorised or allowed to sell them—I have seen the stones produced by Mr. Heath and Mr. Miller—they are similar to what were at Rotherhithe.

WILLIAM HEATH . I bought about twenty pieces of stones of Mr. Winter, Mr. Sargent has seen them, and I think they are the stones he has iden
tified.
ROBERT WINTER . The stones I sold to Mr. Heath I bought of the prisoner—I found them at Rotherhithe—I paid him 2d. a foot for them—they amounted to 1l. 2s. 6d.

Prisoner. I had the stuff given me. Witness. I believe Mr. Nottingham, the commissioner, gave the prisoner some stones; I was present, and believe I heard him give them to him—I told the Magistrate so—Mr. Nottingham, is since dead.
NOT GUILTY .

2580.
JOHN SIMMONDS was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Au
gust, 1 jacket, value 3s. 6d.; the goods of
Joseph Stoyle.
JOSEPH STOYLE . I lodge at Paddington. On the 7th of August I left a bag containing a jacket at the Castle, in Tooley-street—on Friday I went for
it, and it was gone—this is it—I found it in the prisoner's box at his lodgings.
GEORGE OBBARD (police-constable M 108.) I got this jacket and bag from the prosecutor.
JOHN HARRIS . I heard the prisoner say that the box the jacket was in was his—it was corded, and he lodged in the house—I saw the jacket in the chest where some of my things were found.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2581.
WILLIAM KELLARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, 4lbs. weight of nails, value 1s., the goods of
John Scovell and others, his masters.

ROBERT BINES . I am shipping clerk in the service of John Scovell and Sons, at their wharf, in Tooley-street; the prisoner had been a cooper in their employ for twelve years. On the 21st of July, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I desired him to go into the counting-house, and told him to take off his hat, which he did—I found these nails in it—there are 4lbs.—they had come from the cooperage, which the prisoner had possession of—he had no authority whatever to take them away—they were precisely the sort of nails that we use in coopering tallow-casks, which was his occupation—he was going off the premises.

WILLIAM THRUSSELL (police-constable M 148.) I was called to the pro
secutor's premises, and received the prisoner in charge, and these nails.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into one of the warehouses, and saw them loose on the head of a cask; I threw them into my hat, and the witness called me; I put my hat on my head inadvertently, and he asked what I had in my hat; I showed him them; I was going to put them where I generally keep them.
NOT GUILTY .

2582.
JAMES JENNINGS was indicted
for unlawfully having in his possession counterfeit coin; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

2583.
THOMAS RIPPON was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin.

DAVID DE LANEY . I am a cheesemonger. The prisoner came to my shop on the 12th of August for a quarter of a pound of cheese—he gave me a shilling—I found it was bad—I asked him where he got it—he said he was not aware it was bad—I gave him and the shilling to the officer.

JOHN CONSTABLE (police-constable M 43.) I took the prisoner—as I was taking him to the station, there is an open ditch near to the shop—he put his hand to his mouth, and threw a quantity of coin into the ditch—two shillings rested on the side of the ditch—I kept my eye on them till I saw them got by the street-keeper—these are them, and this is the one I got from Mr. De Laney.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These shillings are all counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.

GUILTY .* Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2584.
ELLEN M'CARTHY was indicted
for a like offence.
CLARA DAVIS . I am the wife of John Davis. The prisoner came to our

shop on the 3rd of August for a quarter of a pound of boiled beef—my hus
band served her—she put a shilling across the counter—I gave her change, and put it into a basin, where there was nothing else but coppers—she came again between eight and nine o'clock in the evening for a pint of table beer, and gave me a shilling—I put it into a mug, in which was nothing but farthings—after I had closed the shop, I took the shillings out of the basin and mug, and gave them to my husband, to see if they were good—he told me to take care of them, and I put them both into a tea-cup in the cupboard—I afterwards gave them to the officer.

JOHN DAVIS . I am the husband of Clara Davis. The prisoner came on the 3rd of August for a quarter of a pound of beef—I cut it—I saw her pass the money over to my wife—when we closed the shop at night I discovered that it was a bad shilling—on the 9th she came again—I am positive she is the woman—she had a pint of table beer, and passed a shilling over the counter into my hand—I stopped her from going away—she cried, and fought, and used bad language—I got the officer, and gave him the three shillings.
EDMUND MATTHEWS (police-constable M 68.) I received on the 9th of August two shillings from Mrs. Davis, and one from Mr. Davis—I produce the three.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These three shillings are all counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

2585.
MARY ANN KING was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counter
feit coin.

ELIZABETH MOWAT . I am the wife of David Bennison Mowatt. The prisoner came on the 8th of July, and bought half a peck of peas, which came to 3d.—she gave me a shilling, which I put into my pocket—I had nothing else there but two sixpences and a fourpenny-piece—she came again within half an hour for six pounds of potatoes—I served her—she gave me a shilling—I gave her 6d., and put that shilling into my pocket—I served no other person that morning—I went to a grocer's, and offered the two shillings—he weighed them, and said they were bad—I brought them home, and gave them to my husband—he gave them back to me, and I wrapped them in paper, and put them on the mantelpiece, into a little cup—on the Tues
day following she came again for four pounds of potatoes, and gave me a shilling—I told her I had not got change—I ran over to my husband to get change—he gave me change, and followed the prisoner—I gave the other two shillings to Bush.

DAVID BENNISON MOWATT . I am the witness's husband. On the 8th of July she showed me two shillings, which I bent—on the 11th of July she came over and showed me another shilling—I gave her change, and kept the shilling in my pocket till I gave it to the officer—I received the two bent shillings from Bush, and gave them to the officer.
THOMAS BUSH . I received the two shillings from my mistress, and gave them to my master.
JOSEPH KENT (police-constable L 164.) I took the prisoner and received these three shillings from Mr. Mowatt.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are all counterfeit, and cast in one mould.
Prisoners Defence. He said he took a great deal of bad money, and he would make me suffer for all.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Six Months.

2586.
EMMA THOMAS was indicted
for a like offence.

CLARA BENNETT . I am the daughter of Thomas Bennett, a beer-seller—the prisoner came to my father's on the 10th of August for half a pint of porter—she put down a shilling—I put it into my mouth, and nearly bit it in half—I said it was a bad one—she said, "Oh is it?"—she paid me with a good shilling, and took up the bad one, and went away.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you know her before? A. No, she was there a little while—I was at Union-hall on another charge, and saw her there, and recognized her—I know it was her, because I went after her, she came back and abused me—she went next door, and bought a sheet of paper.

EMMA BROSTER . I am bar-maid at the New-inn, Westminster-bridge-road. On the 11th of August the prisoner came for half a pint of porter—she gave me a bad shilling—I told her it was bad, and she gave me a half-crown—I gave her the change—I then called Mr. Williams, my employer, and marked the shilling in his presence—he gave it to the officer immediately.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen the prisoner before? A. Yes—she had uttered a bad shilling a week previous.

JANE ANN BOWDLEY . I am bar-maid at the Old Red Lion, Westminster-bridge—the prisoner came there on the 11th of August for half a pint of porter, which came to 1d.—she gave me a shilling to take for it—I saw di
rectly it was a bad one—I took it to my master, and gave it to him.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you ever seen her before? A. No, I dare say she was there five minutes—I took particular notice of her, because the po
liceman had been in.
ALPHONSO MACKINTOSH . I am the master of Bowdley. On the 11th of August the prisoner was at my bar—Bowdley gave me a bad shilling—I marked it, called the policeman, and gave it him.
RICHARD GREEN (police-constable L 182.) I received this shilling from Mr. Mackintosh, and this other from Miss Broster.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit, and both from the same mould.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

2587.
CHARLES LAWRENCE was indicted
for a like offence.

WILLIAM COOMBE . I am a licensed victualler. The prisoner came to me on the 2nd of August for a pint of beer, and tendered me a counterfeit shilling—I said that sort would not do for me, it was a bad one—I cut it asunder, gave him the pieces back, and he paid me a good shilling—I sent information to the police.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you sure the prisoner is the person? A. Yes, he was there two or three minutes—I keep the Plough, in Lordship-lane—a great many persons come there, but there were none there then—I took particular notice of the prisoner.

GEORGE MIDDLECOTT . My brother keeps the Greyhound, at Dulwich. On the 2nd of Aug., the prisoner came to his house—he had a pot of half and half, and gave me a bad half-crown—I gave it to my sister, and she bent it on the pewter—I gave it him back—he went into the tap room—he paid for his half and half with a good sixpence—I had seen bad money before—I am certain the half-crown was bad.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. No—he was in the house an hour—I saw him for about five minutes at the bar.
CHARLES SIMMONDS (police-constable P 153.) I went to the Greyhound, on the 2nd of Aug., I found the prisoner there—I found a half-crown in his
pocket—I took him to the station—in taking off his boots I found two bad shillings, a sixpence, and one shilling, and a sixpence fell out which Trigg got.

THOMAS TRIGG (police-constable P 262.) I was at the Greyhound—I took the man who was in company with the prisoner—the prisoner was searched by Simmonds—I picked up a shilling, and a sixpence which I saw fall out of his boot on the floor.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are all counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Year.

2588.
WILLIAM HALLIFAX and
WILLIAM UNDERWOOD were indicted for
a like offence.

SARAH MADDISON . I am the wife of John Maddison, a stationer, at Dul
wich. On the 29th of July, from one to half-past one o'clock, Hallifax came for a sheet of paper, and a stick of sealing wax—they came to 3d.—he gave me half-a-crown—I put it in the till—there was a George the Fourth half-crown there before—I noticed that the half-crown that Hallifax gave me was a George the Third—I had not occasion to look into the till for about half an hour, when my husband told me—I then took the two half-crowns out, and found the George the Third one was a bad one—I gave it to my husband, and he returned it to me—I afterwards gave it to him, and saw him give it to the policeman—I saw Hallifax again on the Sunday evening at the station—I am quite certain he is the person.

JOHN MADDISON . I am the witness' husband. On the 29th of July, Underwood came about half-past two o'clock for a memorandum book and a pencil—he gave me a half-crown—I gave him 2s. 3d. change, and put the half-crown in my mouth—I bit it, and threw it down on the counter—I said it was bad—he took it up and said, "I don't-think it is"—I said, "I am certain it is, I don't intend to take it"—he said, "I must go to my master and get it changed"—he gave me back the 2s. 3d., left the things and went away—I had suspicion, and went to the door, and told a person who was going by if he saw a policeman to desire him to look after Underwood—I then went to the back of my house, got the other half-crown from my wife, and gave it to the policeman—I then pursued Underwood—he ran away—I saw him throw the half-crown into a pond—Eagles came—he went into the pond, and found the half-crown, gave it into my hand, and I gave it to the policeman.

JOSEPH EAGLES . I saw the prisoners together on the 29th of July, about half-past one o'clock—I went into the cricket ground, and saw them—one was going towards Mr. Maddison's shop, and the other was five of six roods off looking over a fence—I heard a cry of "Stop thief"—I got through the hedge, and saw the man running across a field—I met Mr. Maddison—I searched the pond, and found the half-crown, which I gave to Mr. Meredith—I went with the policeman after the prisoner in a cab.

JOHN PALMER SIMMONDS (police-constable P 24.) On the 29th of July I saw the prisoners together in Brixton-road—they saw Eagles speak to me—they went off—I took a cab, went after them, and took them—Mr. Maddison gave me this half-crown.
BARTHOLOMEW HERRING (police-sergeant P 7.) Mr. Maddison gave me a half-crown—this is it.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These are both counterfeit, and both cast in the same mould.

HALLIFAX—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

UNDERWOOD—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

2589.
EMMA HOLT was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of Aug., I bonnet, value 1s. 6d.; 6 yards of ribbon, 3s.; 2 pairs of gloves, 2s., 3/4 of a yard of lawn, 1s. 6d.; 1 pocket handkerchief, 6d.; and 3 artificial flowers, 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Thomas Edmund Butler, her master.

THOMAS EDMUND BUTLER . I am a linen-draper, and live at North Brix
ton. The prisoner had been in my service about six weeks, and was leaving me—on the 17th of Aug. her boxes were packed up, and I desired them to be opened—they were not opened in my presence, but I was by my wife's side, and heard her acknowledge that she had taken this bonnet and ribbon from my stock, that it was her first offence, and she begged I would let her go—I gave her in charge—the officer asked the prisoner to give up her key—we then went back, opened her box, and found some gloves, which correspond with some of mine, these flowers, which have my mark on, and this handkerchief, which has my wife's mark on it.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. This is a very common bonnet? A. It is worth 1s. 6d.—it has my shop mark on it, which is invariably taken off when they are sold—I know this ribbon well—it is an old shopkeeper—it is a very good ribbon.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 18.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Seven Days.

2590.
CAROLINE LETTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of July, 2 printed books, value 2s. 6d.; 3 towels, 2s.; and 1 pinafore, 6d.; the goods of
James M'Intyre, her master.

MARY M'INTYRE . I am the wife of James M'Intyre. In July last the prisoner was employed as a nurse to attend on me—I missed two books, three towels, and a pinafore—these are them—I saw them found in her box on the 3rd of Aug., when she was going away.
Prisoner. They took out what they liked, and claimed it; they took my mother's Bible. Witness. I will swear to these towels; they have my name on them, and these books.
SUSANNAH FREEMAN . I saw these articles taken out of the prisoner's box.
Prisoner. These were my own things, which I have had for years; Mr. M'Intyre was tearing up these books; I said, "What a pity, I should like to read them;" I own I took them to read.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 51.—
Confined Three Months.

2591.
JOHN BERKLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of July, 1152 pipes, value 12s.; and 1 basket, 2s.; the goods of
Richard Ryder, his master.

RICHARD RYDER . I live in Fore-street, Lambeth—the prisoner was in my service. On the 25th of July, I gave him 1152 pipes to take to Mr. Hardy, in Wellington-square—he ought to have come back the same evening, and brought 12s., or the pipes; he did not return—I never saw the pipes nor him, till I found him in the Swan and Horse-shoe, enlisted for a soldier.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You asked him what he had done with the pipes, and he gave you a saucy answer? A. Yes—I do not know that I have ever sent him round with pipes to sell where he could—I had paid him his wages on the Saturday night before he went away, all but 1s. 6d.—he worked with me on the Monday, and on Tuesday he left—he boarded with me—I believe I owe his mother half-a-crown.
GEORGE HARDY . I did not receive these pipes on the 25th of July—I did not see the prisoner on that day.

Cross-examined. Q. Were you at home all day? A. Yes—it was im
possible for eight gross of pipes to come without my knowing it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

div0.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, THE 18TH OF SEPTEMBER.
